questions.question: The maturity period of groundnut in month is
questions.correction: Maturity period is the time needed for the plant to reach maturity. It is a term that is not well defined in plants, but in this case it refers to a point in plant growth where you can either see flowers, in the case of annual flowers, or pick vegetables in the case of vegetable seed plants. Groundnut (Arachis hypogea) maturity period is between four to five months.

questions.question: Oil palm trees do well in soils with pH level of
questions.correction: Oil palm, (Elaeis guineensis), is an African tree in the palm family (Arecaceae), cultivated as a source of oil. The oil palm is grown extensively in its native West and Central Africa, as well as in Malaysia and Indonesia. Oil Palm (Elaeis guinensis) requires a pH scale of 5.5 to 6.5 i.e. it requires a pH scale which is acidic. Therefore, 5.5 - 6.5.

questions.question: The optimum temperature for storing yam tuber under cold storage is
questions.correction: The majority of the world's yam production takes place in Africa, and the rest of it in Asia. The optimum temperature for storing yam tuber under cold storage is 280K (7°C). Therefore, 7°C is correct.

questions.question: Dura, Tenera and Pisifera are all cultivated varieties of
questions.correction: There are different varieties of oil palm: dura palms have kernels with a thick shell; pisifera palms have kernels with no shell; tenera palms have kernels with a thin shell. Dure, Tenera and Pisifera are cultivate varieties of oil palm. Choice B is correct.

questions.question: The non-oil crop among the following is
questions.correction: OIL-BEARING CROPS OR OIL CROPS include both annual (usually called oilseeds) and perennial plants whose seeds, fruits or mesocarp and nuts are valued mainly for the edible or industrial oils that are extracted from them. Choice B, A and C are oil crops but choice D is a leguminous crop. Therefore, choice D is correct.

questions.question: A variety of oil palm is
questions.correction: There are different varieties of oil palm: dura palms have kernels with a thick shell; pisifera palms have kernels with no shell; tenera palms have kernels with a thin shell. Tenera is a variety of oil palm. Choice C is correct

questions.question: Fertilizer application in maize should be completed before
questions.correction: Fertilization or fertilizer application is the supplemental application of plant nutrients to crop plants to augment the supply from natural sources. This consists of applying nutrient-containing materials, called fertilizers, generally into the soil in proximity to receptor plants.

questions.question: Ideal pH for coffee cultivation is
questions.correction: Coffee is cultivated in many places in tropical Latin America, Asia and Africa between the Tropic of Cancer and the Tropic of Capricorn. It grows best in places with rich soil, reliable rainfall and altitudes between 3000 and 6000 feet. As a rule, the higher the elevation the coffee is grown the better the quality. The ideal pH of coffee is between 6.5 to 7.5. Therefore, choice D is correct.

questions.question: Which of the following nutrient is highly immobile in plants?
questions.correction: Mobile nutrients are nitrogen in the form of nitrate, phosphorus (P) in the form of phosphate, potassium (K), magnesium (Mg), chlorine (Cl), zinc (Zn) and molybdene (Mo). Calcium (Ca), sulfur (S), iron (Fe), boron (B) and copper (Cu) are immobile. Boron (B) is highly immobile because of its size. Therefore, choice A is correct.

questions.question: Blast of rice is a
questions.correction: Blast is caused by the fungus Magnaporthe oryzae. It can affect all above ground parts of a rice plant: leaf, collar, node, neck, parts of panicle, and sometimes leaf sheath. Blast of rice is a fungal disease. Therefore, choice C is correct.

questions.question: A soil may be called as alkaline when the pH of the soil is more than
questions.correction: Alkali, or Alkaline, soils are clay soils with high pH (> 8.5), a poor soil structure and a low infiltration capacity. Often they have a hard calcareous layer at 0.5 to 1 metre depth. A soil may be called as alkaline when the pH of the soil is more than 7.0 pH scale than is less than 7.0 is acidic while pH scale that is greater than 7.0 is alkaline. pH scale that is equal to 7.0 is neutral. Therefore, choice C is correct.

questions.question: Which of the following requires Silicon (Si) for its growth?
questions.correction: Silicon has been found to improve drought tolerance and delay wilting in certain crops where irrigation is withheld and may enhance the plant's ability to resist micronutrient and other metal toxicities (i.e. aluminum, copper, iron, manganese, zinc, etc.). Rice (Oryza Sativa) needs Silicon (si) for its growth. Choice C is correct.

questions.question: Phalaris minor is a crop associated wood with crop
questions.correction: Phalaris minor is a species of grass native to North Africa, Europe, and South Asia. The bunchgrass is widely naturalised elsewhere. Common names include little seed canary grass, small-seeded canary grass, small canary grass, lesser-canary grass, guli danda (Hindi), and sittee booti (Urdu). Phalaris minor is a crop associated with wheat. Choice A is correct.

questions.question: What is crop rotation?
questions.optiona: Growing of crops one after the other in a particular sequence
questions.optionb: Growing more than one crop at a time
questions.optionc: Growing of an associate crop in between the rows of the main crop
questions.optiond: Growing of crops together in strips
questions.correction: Crop rotation is the practice of growing a series of dissimilar or different types of crops in the same area in sequenced seasons. It is done so that the soil of farms is not used for only one set of nutrients. It helps in reducing soil erosion and increases soil fertility and yield crop. Choice A is correct. Crop rotation involves the growing of crops one after other in a particular sequence

questions.question: The main mode of infection of rinderpest disease in cattle is through
questions.correction: Rinderpest virus spreads when healthy, susceptible animals are exposed to infected droplets, either in the breath of a sick animal or in its virus-rich secretions or excretions. On rare occasions, transmission has allegedly occurred through indirect contact with contaminated bedding, fodder or water. The main made of infection of tinderpest disease is through inhalation of infected air by cattles. Choice D is correct

questions.question: The pox disease in livestock are caused by
questions.correction: Pox disease, any of a complex of viral diseases in human beings and domestic animals, marked chiefly by eruptions of the skin and mucous membranes. Sheep pox and rabbit pox are spread by airborne infectious particles that are inhaled. Horse pox, fowl pox, and mouse pox usually are spread by skin contact. The pox diseases in livestock are caused by viruses. Choice B is correct

questions.question: In poultry nutrition, the minerals that prevent the laying of thin-shelled eggs are
questions.correction:
The minerals that prevents the laying of thin-shelled eggs are calcium and phosphorus (Ca and P).
Thin-shelled eggs in poultry nutrition laid as a result of the deficiency of calcium and phosphorus. Too much phosphorous in the diet will decrease shell thickness. Therefore, choice A is correct.

questions.question: In animal nutrition, iodine is essential for the production of
questions.correction: Iodine is important in the synthesis of the thyroid hormones, thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3), which regulate energy metabolism in animals. The thyroid hormones are responsible for setting the basal metabolic rate that is a component of the energy needed for the maintenance of the body. Iodine is essential for the production of thyroxine in animals. Therefore, choice B is correct.

questions.question: The process of mating in sheep is termed
questions.correction: Tupping means mating in sheep, or the mating season (autumn, for a spring-lambing flock). The process of mating in sheep is termed tupping. Choice C is correct.

questions.question: Fertilizers are applied to fishponds to serve as
questions.correction: Fertilizers in fish farming are applied to fishponds to serve as nutrients for plankton. A 20-20-5 fish pond fertilizer is 20 percent nitrogen (N), 20 percent phosphorus (P205) and 5 percent potassium (K20) by weight. The remaining percentage is inert material and binders. Phosphorus is generally the limiting nutrient in ponds; little nitrogen and usually no potassium is generally needed. Choice C is correct.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a breed of rabbits?
questions.correction: As of 2017, there were at least 305 breeds of domestic rabbit in 70 countries around the world. A rabbit breed is a distinct variety created through natural selection or, more often, though selective breeding for specific characteristics, including size, fur (length, quality, or color), feed conversion ratio, climate adaptability, or temperament. New zealand white, Chinchilla and californian white are breed of rabbits. Therefore, choice B is correct.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of the reproduction system of a hen?
questions.correction: The reproductive system of a chicken hen is made up of two parts: the ovary and the oviduct. Ova (yolks) develop in the ovary. When an ovum (singular of ova) has matured, it is released from the ovary into the oviduct. This release of the ovum is ovulation. Ureter is the correct option. Therefore, choice D is correct

questions.question: A good silage should be free of
questions.correction: Silage is a type of fodder made from green foliage crops which have been preserved by acidification, achieved through fermentation. It can be fed to cattle, sheep and other such ruminants. Choice A is correct. A good silage must contain good nutrients, moisture and fibre.

questions.question: The most unreliable source of power on the farm is
questions.correction: Farm operations are done by different sources of power, namely human, animal, oil engine, tractor, power tiller, electricity and renewable energy (biogas, solar and wind). Human beings are the main source of power for operating small tools and implements. Choice B is the most unreliable source of farm power and choice B is wind.

questions.question: The farm machinery used to sow seeds and apply fertilizer at the same time is
questions.correction: In agriculture, a harrow (often called a set of harrows in a plurale tantum sense) is an implement for breaking up and smoothing out the surface of the soil. In this way it is distinct in its effect from the plough, which is used for deeper tillage. The farm machinery used to sow seeds and apply fertilizer at the same time is a harrow. Therefore, choice D is correct.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a source of farm power?
questions.correction: Farm operations are done by different sources of power, namely human, animal, oil engine, tractor, power tiller, electricity and renewable energy (biogas, solar and wind). Human beings are the main source of power for operating small tools and implements. Choice D is correct. Plough is not 2 source of farm power.

questions.question: Farm survey equipment include the following except
questions.correction:
Farm surveying is the process of measuring and mapping out the position, height, size and boundary of an area of farmland. Chain is not a farm survey equipment but it is kind of used in measurement.
Therefore, choice D is correct

questions.question: Which of the following required daily checking in a tractor?
questions.correction:
A tractor is a farm vehicle that is used to pull farm machinery and to provide the energy needed for the machinery to work. Maintenance tasks include:
- Start with a visual inspection of your small farm tractor.
- Check the tractor's radiator-fluid level.
- Check the fan's drive belt for wear and tension, and visually inspect the radiator core and grill screen.
- Top off the tractor's fuel tank.
- Check the tractor's oil.
- Check the tractor's tire pressure.
- Check air filter (optional).
The engine oil of a tractor requires daily checking. Therefore, choice B is correct

questions.question: In order to eliminate food shortage, farm as should
questions.optionc: shift from crop to animal production
questions.correction: In order to eliminate food shortage, farmers should cultivate more varieties of crops. Farmers will need a genetically diverse portfolio of improved crop varieties, suited to a range of agro-ecosystems and farming practices, and resilient to climate change. Choice A is correct.

questions.question: The following are importance of agriculture except
questions.optiond: Provision of market for industrial goods
questions.correction:
Choice C is correct
Benefits of agriculture include:
- Source of Livelihood. Most people's main source of livelihood is farming.
- Contribution to National revenue.
- Supply of Food as well as Fodder.
- Significance to International Trade.
- Marketable Surplus.

Agriculture offers option A, B and D as benefits except C.

questions.question: The following are the features of subsistence agriculture except
questions.optiona: subsistence agriculture is mostly practised by peasant farms
questions.optionb: It requires the use of family labour
questions.optionc: Pests and diseases are not really controlled
questions.optiond: It requires the use of both skilled and unskilled labour
questions.correction:
Features of subsistence farming are as follows:
(a) It is practised by majority of the farmers in the country.
(b) It is characterised by small and scattered land holdings and use of primitive tools.
(c) The farmers do not use fertilisers and high yielding variety of seeds as they are poor.
Choice A, C and B explains the features of subsistence agriculture but option D did not state the feature of subsistence agriculture.
Choice D is correct.

questions.question: Which of the following is a type of land tenure system?
questions.correction:
Five types of land tenure system in Nigeria
- The communal land tenure system.
- Individual Land Tenure.
- Inheritance Tenure System.
- Leasehold Tenure System.
- Gift Tenure System.
Option A is correct. There is no such thing as keyhold land tenure system or the system in choice C and D. The types of land tenure system are;
i. Freehold system
ii. Leasehold system
iii. Communal land tenure system
iv. Land tenure system by inheritance, e.t.c.
There is no such thing as international land tenure system or land tenure system by theft. Therefore, choice A is correct.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a branch of agriculture?
questions.correction:
Branches of agriculture include:
- Agronomy
- Soil Science and Agricultural Chemistry
- Horticulture
- Plant Breeding and Genetics
- Plant Pathology
- Entomology
- Agricultural Economics
- Extension Education
- Agriculture Statistics
- Seed Technology
- Nematology
- Plant Physiology
- Forestry
- Agricultural Biotechnology
- Fishery
Kidding is not branch of agriculture. It is the act of giving birth in rabbits and goats. Choice C is correct

questions.question: The demand for agricultural produce is generally
questions.correction:
Demand for most farm products is inelastic. People can consume only so much then they are satiated. Even if price drops they will not buy much more. When demand is inelastic a drop in price that spurs more quantity being sold results in lower revenue and profit for the producer.
Choice B is correct. A price inelastic demand would mean that an increase in price would not necessarily lead to a decline in quantity demanded or in case it does proportion of quantity change would be lesser vis a vis the change in price.
Demand tends to be price inelastic for agricultural produce for the following reasons.
1. Price changes don't affect consumption much
2. These produce are mostly necessities
3. Possibility of postponement is not there for most of these produce

questions.question: Rural farmers mostly obtain loans from
questions.correction: Loans to agriculture can be financed by different sources of funds such as farmer household savings, capital markets, equity, budget allocations of the government, central bank refinance facilities and international borrowing. Choice D is correct because most rural farmers don't actually have access to merchant banks, IMF, government etc.

questions.question: The type of labour available to peasant farmers is
questions.correction: Peasant farming is a type of farming that is practised by peasant farmers on small farm holdings. The labour is mostly supplied by the farmer and his family. The type of labour available to peasant farmers is family labour because most peasant farmers practise subsistence agriculture. Choice A is correct.

questions.question: The factor of production whose reward is profit is
questions.correction: The important factors of production are: (i) Land (ii) Labour (iii) Capital (iv) Entrepreneur. Whatever is used in producing a commodity is called its inputs. For example, for producing wheat, a farmer uses inputs like soil, tractor, tools, seeds, manure, water and his own services. The factor of production whose reward is profit is entrepreneurship. The reward for land is rent, the reward for labour is wages or salaries while the reward for entrepreneur is profit and the reward for entrepreneur is profit and the reward for capital is interest. Therefore, choice D is correct

questions.question: The wear and tear of farm structures over time is described as
questions.correction: Machinery and equipment are major cost items in farm businesses. Larger ma­chines, new technology, higher prices for parts and new machinery, and higher energy prices have all caused machinery and power costs to rise in recent years. Depreciation is a cost resulting from wear, obsoles­cence, and age of a machine. The degree of me­chanical wear may cause the value of a particular machine to be somewhat above or below the aver­age value for similar machines when it is traded or sold. The introduction of new technology or a major design change may make an older machine suddenly obsolete, causing a sharp decline in its remaining value. But age and accumulated hours of use are usually the most important factors in determining the remaining value of a machine. Choice B is correct. The wear and tear of farm structures overtime is described as depreciation

questions.question: Soil texture can be refered to as
questions.optiona: distribution of soil particles in a given sample
questions.optionb: movement of water through the soil
questions.optionc: Distribution of the different sizes of soil particles
questions.correction: Soil texture is a classification instrument used both in the field and laboratory to determine soil classes based on their physical texture. Soil texture can be determined using qualitative methods such as texture by feel, and quantitative methods such as the hydrometer method. Soil Texture is the classification of soil based on its physical texture and characteristics, particularly the size of the particles that make up the soil.

questions.question: Which one of the following is not a target group of an agricultural Extension agent
questions.correction:
Agricultural extension is the application of scientific research and new knowledge to agricultural practices through farmer education. Extension Agents are employed by land-grant universities and serve the citizens of that particular state by serving as an expert or teacher on a topic relating to economics, community development, agriculture, family, animal production, diet and nutrition. Target group approach simply means that the extension activities are focussed on a specific section of the population but not that the target group participates actively in the development of the extension approach. Agricultural extension always takes place within the social context of the farming population. Political parties are organized group of people with the same political ideology that fields candidates to contest in an election in order to win and implement their agenda.
Other options are related to agriculture except political parties.

questions.question: All but one are qualities of a good extension worker
questions.correction:
Agricultural extension is the application of scientific research and new knowledge to agricultural practices through farmer education. organisational ability, clear judgement, initiative which qualities helps him to organize and interact with his target groups, but involvement in local politics is not a quality of a good extension worker.

questions.question: Which one of these is not part of a disc plough?
questions.correction:
The disc plough is designed to work in all types of soil for functions such as soil breaking, soil raising, soil turning and soil mixing. It is used to open the new fields and to process the stony areas. It can be used easily at rocky and rooted areas. The basic components of a disc plough are beam, standard, cross-shaft, disc plough body, furrow wheel and scrapers and so on.

Planter is an equipment used in planting dead and it is only used after land preparation, where as disc plough is used for land preparation.

questions.question: One major difference between disc plough and disc harrow is
questions.optiona: Disc plough is used to create wider ridges on the field than disc Harrow
questions.optionb: A disc plough can have up to 54 discs on it at once whereas a disc harrow can have up to 6 disc
questions.optionc: Disc plough is used to tilled the disc harrowed land
questions.optiond: The disc part of plough is notched while that of harrow is round
questions.correction:
Disc plough is used to till the uncultivated land and disc harrow is used to till the disc plow turned land. If the ground has been turned with a dis plow, the disc harrow should be fine. Also if the land is soft light duty disc harrow can used as disc plow to cultivate the land.

questions.correction:

A castrated cockerel is referred to as capon

questions.correction:

questions.question: Newcastle disease is viral diseases that affect which animals?
questions.correction:
Newcastle disease is an infection of domestic poultry and other bird species with virulent Newcastle disease virus (NDV). It is a worldwide problem that presents primarily as an acute respiratory disease, but depression, nervous manifestations, or diarrhea may be the predominant clinical form.

Newcastle disease is an infection of domestic poultry and other bird species with virulent Newcastle disease virus (NDV).

questions.question: All are factors to consider when planning a farmstead except?
questions.correction:
A farmstead is a farm or the part of a farm comprising its main buildings together with adjacent grounds. Farmstead Planning is the first and most important step in designing a farmstead. While it costs very title to change a plan on paper, the expense of altering a finished building can be prohibitive, and a poorly conceived arrangement of buildings can diminish profits far into the future.

Farm stead is the house belonging to a farm and the buildings around it, since it is not used for planting or cultivation, irrigation is not a factor to consider.

questions.question: Legumes are different from grasses, because
questions.optiona: They have lesser protein content than grasses
questions.optionb: They form symbiotic relationship with bacteria, rhizobian, in the nodules of their roofs
questions.correction:
Legumes—primarily clover and alfalfa (lucerne)—have leaves with less structural material and are generally higher in protein, energy, and calcium than grasses. Legumes become less leafy and more stemmy as they mature. Conversely, grass leaves become more lignified as they mature, and are therefore less digestible.

Legumes form symbiotic relationship with bacteria, rhizobium in the nodules of their roots to manufacture nitrogen compounds, which in turn serve as protein in the legumes, and seed being part of their storage form.

questions.question: In which of the soil layer does most biological activity occur?
questions.correction:
The topsoil is the region with the most biological activity. Many organisms live within this layer. Plant roots stretch down into this layer. The roots help to hold the topsoil in place.

A - horizon is the top layer of the soil horizon, it contains decomposed organic matter which is necessary for plant growth and also microorganisms

questions.question: All but one are related to surface irrigation?
questions.correction: Surface irrigation is where water is applied and distributed over the soil surface by gravity. It is by far the most common form of irrigation throughout the world and has been practiced in many areas virtually unchanged for thousands of years. Mole drainage is a subsurface method of draining clay soils that experience regular waterlogging from irrigation or high rainfall

questions.question: The most effective method of controlling or preventing viral diseases in plants is by
questions.correction:
Prevention, or at least alleviation, of the effects of viruses, involves:
(1) Elimination of sources of virus.
(2) Elimination of the virus from infected plants.
(3) Control of vectors.
(4) Breeding for resistance and the use of cross-protection methods.
Each of these approaches to control will be considered.
Planting resistant varieties of a plant/crop is the most effective method of controlling or preventing viral diseases since, the varieties can resist viral infections.

questions.question: Reduction of ten seedlings of maize to two per stand is referred to as
questions.correction: Thinning is a term used in agricultural sciences to mean the removal of some plants, or parts of plants, to make room for the growth of others but does not involve the cutting of the whole tree. Selective removal of parts of a plant such as branches, buds, or roots is typically known as pruning. Thinning is the removal of some or parts of plants, to make room for the growth of others but does not involve the cutting of the whole tree.

questions.question: The causative organism of maize rust is?
questions.correction: Common rust on sweet corn is caused by the fungus Puccinia sorghi. The staggered planting schedules result in high concentrations of fungal spores in the air, originating from early planted fields, at the time when late-planted fields contain young actively growing susceptible plants. Maize rust is caused by a fungus called Puccinia sorghi.

questions.question: Which of the following fruit is a capsule?

A capsule is a type of simple, dry, though rarely fleshy dehiscent fruit produced by many species of angiosperms. Only okra in the options is a capsule.

What is the primary purpose of farm surveying in agriculture?
questions.correction: The primary purpose of farm surveying in agriculture is to accurately map the land boundaries of a farm. Farm surveying involves the measurement and mapping of land to establish property lines, determine field sizes and shapes, and demarcate boundaries between different land parcels.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a farm implement used for soil preparation in agriculture?
questions.correction: A plow is an example of a farm implement used for soil preparation in agriculture. A plow is a tool or implement that is pulled or attached to a tractor or draft animals and is used to break up, loosen, and turn over the soil. It helps in preparing the soil for planting crops by creating furrows or ridges and incorporating organic matter or fertilizer into the soil.

questions.question: What is the importance of agriculture?
questions.optiona: Agriculture has no significant impact on the economy or global trade
questions.optionb: Agriculture is essential for food production and food security
questions.optionc: Agriculture provides employment opportunities only in rural areas
questions.optiond: Agriculture is primarily focused on the production of cash crops for export
questions.correction: Agriculture plays a crucial role in providing food for the growing global population and ensuring food security. It involves the cultivation of crops, rearing of livestock, and production of food products.

questions.question: What is rock weathering and how does it affect agriculture?
questions.optiona: Rock weathering is the process of rocks eroding and washing away from agricultural fields
questions.optionb: Rock weathering is the process of breaking down rocks into smaller fragments
questions.optionc: Rock weathering is the process of rocks decomposing and releasing nutrients into the soil
questions.optiond: Rock weathering is the process of rocks absorbing water and expanding in size
questions.correction: Rock weathering refers to the natural process by which rocks are broken down into smaller fragments over time. This process is influenced by various factors such as temperature, moisture, wind, and the presence of organisms. There are different types of rock weathering, including physical weathering, chemical weathering, and biological weathering.

questions.question: What are biotic factors in an agricultural ecosystem?
questions.optiona: Factors related to the climate and weather
questions.optionb: Factors related to the living organisms
questions.optionc: Factors related to the physical environment
questions.optiond: Factors related to the availability of nutrients
questions.correction: Biotic factors in an agricultural ecosystem refer to the living organisms that influence the ecosystem dynamics and processes. These organisms can directly or indirectly impact agricultural productivity and sustainability.

questions.question: What is the process of removing the horns of cattle called?
questions.correction: Dehorning is the process of removing the horns of livestock. Cattle, sheep, and goats are sometimes dehorned for economic and safety reasons.

questions.question: What is crop science?
questions.optiona: The study of agricultural machinery and equipment
questions.optionb: The study of weather patterns and their impact on crop growth
questions.optionc: The study of soil fertility and nutrient management
questions.optiond: The study of plant genetics and breeding
questions.correction: Crop science is the branch of agriculture that focuses on the scientific study of crops, particularly their genetics, breeding, and improvement. It involves the application of scientific principles and techniques to enhance the productivity, quality, and resilience of crop plants.

questions.question: What are abiotic factors in an agricultural ecosystem?
questions.optiona: Factors related to the living organisms
questions.optionb: Factors related to the availability of nutrients
questions.optionc: Factors related to the climate and weather
questions.optiond: Factors related to the physical environment
questions.correction: Abiotic factors in an agricultural ecosystem are the non-living components of the environment that influence the ecosystem and agricultural productivity.

questions.question: The N'dama breed of cattle is primarily raised for
questions.correction: The N'dama breed of cattle is primarily raised for meat production. N'dama is a breed of cattle indigenous to Africa, and it is well known for its resistance to trypanosomiasis or sleeping sickness. While they can be used for milk production, their primary use is for meat production.

questions.question: Which breed of sheep is commonly found in Nigeria and known for its meat production?
questions.correction: The breed of sheep commonly found in Nigeria and known for its meat production is the West African Dwarf. This breed is small but has a high resistance to trypanosomiasis and other diseases, making it ideal for meat production in the region.

questions.question: Which of the following is a hand tool commonly used in agriculture for cutting grass or crops?
questions.correction: A scythe is a hand tool commonly used in agriculture for cutting grass or crops. It consists of a long, curved blade attached to a handle, and it is used by swinging the blade in a rhythmic motion to cut vegetation close to the ground.

questions.question: What are the important properties of soil in agriculture?
questions.optiona: pH, organic matter content, and water-holding capacity
questions.optionb: Drainage, cation exchange capacity, and soil depth.
questions.correction: Soil properties play a critical role in agricultural practices and the successful cultivation of crops.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a principle of agronomy?
questions.correction: Agronomy is a branch of agricultural science that focuses on crop production and soil management. It involves the application of scientific principles and techniques to maximize crop yield and ensure sustainable agricultural practices.

questions.question: Which of the following is an objective of agricultural development programs?
questions.optiond: Expanding land holdings for large-scale farms
questions.correction: One of the primary objectives of agricultural development programs is to enhance sustainable agricultural practices. These programs aim to promote environmentally friendly and socially responsible farming methods that conserve natural resources, minimize negative impacts on ecosystems, and ensure long-term agricultural productivity.

questions.question: What is agronomy?
questions.optiona: The study of crop production and soil management
questions.optionb: The study of animal breeding and genetics
questions.optionc: The study of agricultural machinery and equipment
questions.optiond: The study of plant diseases and pest control
questions.correction: Agronomy is a branch of agriculture that focuses on the science and technology of crop production and soil management. It involves the study of various aspects related to the growth, development, and management of agricultural crops.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a component of agronomy?
questions.correction: Agronomy is a branch of agriculture that focuses on crop production and the management of agricultural systems. It involves various aspects related to growing and cultivating crops. The main components of agronomy include crop production, soil management, and pest management.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of agricultural technology?
questions.correction: Irrigation is an example of agricultural technology. It involves the artificial application of water to agricultural fields to supplement natural rainfall. Irrigation systems can range from simple methods like surface irrigation to more advanced techniques like drip irrigation or sprinkler systems.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an agent of pollination in plants?
questions.correction: Pollination is the process by which pollen grains are transferred from the male reproductive organs to the female reproductive organs of a plant, enabling fertilization and seed production. Various agents can facilitate pollination, including animals, wind, and water.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a biotic factor in an agricultural ecosystem?
questions.correction: Biotic factors in an agricultural ecosystem refer to the living organisms or biological components that influence the dynamics of the ecosystem. These factors can include plants, animals, microorganisms, and other living organisms that interact with agricultural crops. Crop pests, such as insects, rodents, and pathogens, are examples of biotic factors that can have a significant impact on agricultural systems.

questions.question: What factors influence soil fertility in agriculture?
questions.optionb: Organic matter content and nutrient availability
questions.correction: Soil fertility is influenced by a variety of factors including organic matter content, nutrient availability, pH, soil structure, soil texture, and drainage. Organic matter content and nutrient availability provide the necessary nutrients for plant growth. pH affects the availability of nutrients in the soil. Soil structure affects the soil's ability to hold and supply water, air, and nutrients to plants. Soil texture affects the soil's physical properties and its ability to hold and supply water, air, and nutrients to plants. Drainage affects the soil's ability to supply sufficient water to plants without waterlogging the roots.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a monogastric animal?
questions.correction: A monogastric is an animal with a single-compartmented stomach. Examples of monogastrics include humans, poultry, pigs, horses, rabbits, dogs and cats. Most monogastrics are generally unable to digest much cellulose food materials such as grasses.

questions.question: The Sokoto Gudali is a breed of
questions.correction: The Sokoto Gudali is a breed of cattle. It is one of the largest breeds of cattle in Nigeria and is used for both milk and meat production

questions.question: Which of the following is a method of plant propagation that involves the use of plant parts?
questions.correction: Grafting is a method of plant propagation that involves the use of plant parts. It is a horticultural technique whereby tissues of plants are joined so as to continue their growth together. The upper part of the combined plant is called the scion while the lower part is called the rootstock. The success of this joining requires that the vascular tissues grow together and such joining is called inosculation.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a branch of agriculture?
questions.correction: Zoology is the branch of biology that deals with the study of animals, their behavior, physiology, classification, and distribution. While the study of animals is important in understanding their interactions with agricultural systems, it is not considered a direct branch of agriculture.

questions.question: The Balami is a breed of
questions.correction: The Balami is a breed of sheep. It is one of the domestic sheep found in Africa, particularly in Nigeria. Therefore, the correct answer is 'Sheep'.

questions.question: What are the main components of soil?
questions.correction: Soil is a complex mixture of different components that collectively contribute to its properties and fertility. The main components of soil include sand, silt, clay, organic matter, minerals, water, nutrients, and microorganisms.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common problem in agricultural economics and extension?
questions.optiond: Lack of access to modern technology
questions.correction: Agricultural economics and extension deal with the application of economic methods to optimizing the decisions made by agricultural producers. A common problem in this field is the lack of access to modern technology. This can hinder the efficiency and productivity of agricultural practices. Excessive government regulations, overreliance on chemical inputs, and inadequate market infrastructure can also be challenges in agriculture, but they are not specific to agricultural economics and extension.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes agricultural marketing?
questions.optiona: The process of producing agricultural goods
questions.optionb: The transportation of agricultural products to consumers
questions.optionc: The storage and preservation of agricultural goods
questions.optiond: The promotion and selling of agricultural products
questions.correction: Agricultural marketing refers to the activities involved in the promotion and selling of agricultural products. It encompasses various processes, such as market research, product promotion, pricing, distribution, and sales.

questions.question: What is subsistence agriculture?
questions.correction: Subsistence agriculture refers to a type of farming where the primary purpose is to meet the food and basic needs of a family or community. It is characterized by small-scale farming practices with limited use of modern technology and resources. The produce from subsistence agriculture is primarily consumed by the farmer and their family, with little or no surplus for sale.

questions.question: What is soil conservation, and why is it important in agriculture?
questions.optiona: Soil conservation involves the removal of topsoil for agricultural purposes
questions.optionb: Soil conservation refers to the preservation and sustainable management of soil resources
questions.optionc: Soil conservation aims to maximize crop yields through intensive farming practices
questions.optiond: Soil conservation focuses on increasing soil fertility through the use of chemical fertilizers
questions.correction: Soil conservation is the practice of protecting and managing the soil to prevent erosion, degradation, and loss of fertility. It involves implementing various techniques and practices to ensure the long-term sustainability and productivity of agricultural lands.

questions.question: What are the main differences between monocot and dicot plants?
questions.optiona: Monocots have parallel leaf veins, while dicots have branched leaf veins
questions.optionb: Monocots have flower parts in multiples of three, while dicots have flower parts in multiples of four or five
questions.optiond: Monocots have fibrous root systems, while dicots have taproot systems
questions.correction: Monocots and dicots are differentiated by several characteristics. Monocots have parallel leaf veins, while dicots have branched leaf veins. This is due to the different growth patterns of the two types of plants. Monocots have flower parts in multiples of three, while dicots have flower parts in multiples of four or five. This is due to the different evolutionary paths of the two types of plants. Monocots have fibrous root systems, while dicots have taproot systems. This is due to the different needs of the two types of plants, with monocots typically being grasses and cereals that benefit from a fibrous root system, and dicots being broad-leaved plants that benefit from a taproot system.

questions.question: What is agricultural ecology?
questions.optiona: The study of genetics and breeding techniques used in agriculture
questions.optionb: The study of climate change and its effects on agricultural productivity
questions.optionc: The study of ecological processes in agricultural systems and their interactions
questions.optiond: The study of agricultural practices and their economic impact on farmers
questions.correction: Agricultural ecology is a branch of science that focuses on understanding the ecological processes and interactions within agricultural systems. It involves studying the relationships between crops, livestock, pests, beneficial organisms, soil, water, and the surrounding environment.

questions.question: What is a soil profile, and what information does it provide in agricultural practices?
questions.optiona: A soil profile is an analysis of soil microorganisms and their activities
questions.optionb: A soil profile is an assessment of soil compaction and drainage
questions.optionc: A soil profile is a vertical section of the soil that reveals its layers or horizons
questions.optiond: A soil profile is a measurement of soil pH and nutrient levels
questions.correction: A soil profile refers to a vertical section of the soil that displays the different layers or horizons of the soil. It provides valuable information about the composition, structure, and properties of the soil, which is crucial in agricultural practices.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of farmstead planning in agriculture?
questions.correction: The primary purpose of farmstead planning in agriculture is to ensure the efficient utilization of available space. Farmstead planning involves designing and organizing the physical layout of the farm, including buildings, structures, roads, and other facilities, in a manner that optimizes space usage.

questions.question: What is animal production in agriculture?
questions.optiona: The management and care of livestock for various purposes
questions.optionb: The breeding and genetic improvement of animals for specific traits
questions.optionc: The production of animal-based products such as milk and eggs
questions.optiond: The cultivation of crops for animal consumption
questions.correction: Animal production in agriculture refers to the practice of managing and caring for livestock for various purposes.

questions.question: What is pollination in plants?
questions.optiona: The dispersal of seeds by wind or animals
questions.optionb: The transfer of pollen from the anther to the stigma of a flower
questions.optionc: The process of seed formation after fertilization
questions.optiond: The production of flowers by a plant
questions.correction: Pollination is the process by which pollen grains from the male reproductive organ of a flower (anther) are transferred to the female reproductive organ (stigma) of the same or a different flower.

questions.question: What is commercial agriculture?
questions.optiona: Large-scale farming for profit and market-oriented production
questions.optionc: Small-scale farming with limited use of modern technology
questions.correction: Commercial agriculture refers to farming practices that are primarily focused on generating profit through the sale of agricultural products in the market. It involves large-scale cultivation of crops or raising of livestock with the aim of maximizing productivity and economic returns.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an agricultural extension method used to disseminate information to farmers?
questions.correction: Farmer field schools are an example of an agricultural extension method used to disseminate information to farmers. Farmer field schools are structured learning programs where farmers actively participate in hands-on training and field demonstrations.

questions.question: Which of the following are branches of agriculture?
questions.correction: Agriculture is a broad field that encompasses various branches or disciplines focused on different aspects of plant and animal production. Among the given options, Agronomy and Horticulture are the branches of agriculture.

questions.question: What is the primary goal of agricultural extension services in the field of agricultural economics?
questions.correction: The primary goal of agricultural extension services in the field of agricultural economics is to enhance market access for farmers. Agricultural extension services provide farmers with information, training, and support to improve their understanding of market dynamics, marketing strategies, and value chain development.

questions.question: The following conditions are necessary for germination except
questions.correction: Conditions necessary for germination of seeds are adequate moisture,viable seed (living embryo),optimum temperature,adequate air and zero temperature is not included

questions.question: _________ is the sowing of seed by drilling with stick or knife, followed by dropping seeds and covering them
questions.correction: Drilling: sowing a seed by drilling with stick or knife, followed by dropping seeds and covering them

questions.question: The process whereby the embryo of a seed resumes growth under favourable conditions is called
questions.correction: Germination: the process whereby the embryo of a seed resumes growth under favourable conditions. Germination is the sprouting of seed.

questions.question: ______ refers to the appearance of a seedling above soil level.
questions.correction: Emergence: this refers to the appearance of a seedling above soil level.

questions.question: The young plants that emerge during germination are called
questions.correction: seedling is a young plants grown from seed, rather than from cutting

questions.question: One of the followings is not a basic consideration in planting operations
questions.correction: Basic consideration in planting operations are planting depth, planting time, planting space

questions.question: __________ is the distance of the sown seed in the soil from the soil surface
questions.correction: Planting depth is the distance of the sown seed in the soil from the soil surface. The correct planting depth is one that places the seed where it can imbibe water

questions.question: __________ is a special place prepared for raising seedlings which are later taken to the field for proper planting.
questions.correction:
Nursery is a special place prepared for raising seedlings which are later taken to the field for proper planting (transplanting).
Seedlings are grown in nursery beds, seed trays or boxes, basket or polythene bags may be used as boxes. E.g. of such crops are cocoa, kola, tomatoes, citrus etc.

questions.question: The following are post planting operations except
questions.correction: Post planting operations are the operations carried out after planting. It creates a good condition and proper maintenance for plants growth e.g Thinning, Supplying, Mulching,Harvesting

questions.question: The removal of excess seedlings from a seedbed after the viable seeds have germinated is
questions.correction: Thinning is the removal of excess, weak or not well positioned seedlings from a seedbed after the viable seeds have germinated

questions.question: _________ is the artificial watering of farmland
questions.correction: Irrigation(watering) is the artificial watering of farmland especially during dry season

questions.question: Which of the following methods of storage is used for grains
questions.correction: Silos is a tall round metal tower or pit on a farm used to store grain

questions.question: Some seeds are raised in the nursery because
questions.optiond: So that they can get enough sunshine
questions.correction: The seedlings are weak and may not survive in field. They require protection from sunlight and rainfall.

questions.question: This is the removal of unwanted plants on the farm
questions.correction:
Weeding is the removal of unwanted plants (weeds) from the farm. It can be done with the aid of cutlass and hoes or by spraying herbicide. It is done for the following reasons:
-To avoid competition for nutrients, moisture, sunlight and space between crops and weed.
-To prevent the buildup of pest and pathogens.

questions.question: The following problems are usually associated with subsistence agriculture except
questions.optionc: It requires a large area of land
questions.correction: The practice of commercial agriculture requires several hectares of land to operate successfully.

questions.question: Which of the following processes is not used in rice processing
questions.correction: Fermentation is the breakdown of a substance by bacteria, yeasts or other microorganisms typically invovolving effervescence and the giving off of heat. Threshing, Winnowing and perboiling are used in rice processing.

questions.question: Primary tillage is also known as
questions.correction: Ploughing is cutting through the soil and making it into lumps or clods of soil. It is called primary tillage. While secondary tillage (harrowing) is the use of harrow to break down the large clods of soil into fine particles and making it ready for ridging

questions.question: Climatic factors which affects organisms include the following except
questions.correction: A rock is a solid collection of mineral grains that grow or become cemented together. some rocks are large while others are small.

questions.question: The following animals are polygastric animals except
questions.correction: A polygastric digestive system is a system comprising of a four-chambered stomach. This form of the digestive system is common among ruminants such as cattle, sheep and deer

questions.question: Which branch of ecology deals with the study of an individual organism and its interaction with the environment is
questions.correction: Autecology is concerned with the study of an individual organism, or a single species of organism and its environment. For example the study of a single cattle and its environment.

questions.question: The vertical section of the soil showing series of horizontal layers of different types of soil is called
questions.correction: Soil profile is defined as the vertical section of the soil, showing series of horizontal layers of different types of soil. These horizontal layers are called horizons.

questions.question: The A-Horizon of soil profile is also called the
questions.correction: The A-Horizon, also called the top soil, represents the surface layer of the soil profile. This horizon contains more organic matter than other horizons. The A horizon, the top soil, is the most weathered and leached of all the soil horizons.

questions.question: The B-Horizon of soil profile is also called the
questions.correction: The B-horizon, also called the sub-soil, is the next horizon immediately after the top soil. It is rich in minerals which are carried or leached down by percolating water.

questions.question: ____________ is said to occur when a ration does not provide all the food nutrients in adequate quantities needed by animal.
questions.correction: Malnutrition is said to occur when a ration (amount of feed provided to an animal per day) does not provide all the food nutrients(carbohydrate, protein,fats and oils, vitamins, minerals, water and other feed additives) in adequate quantities. Those nutrients wanting are said to be deficient which eventually results in nutritional disease.

questions.question: The feed that is regularly offered to or consumed by the animal is called
questions.correction: A ration is defined as the feed that is regularly offered to or consumed by the animal. Diets are formulated to meet specific metabolic or physiological functions which include growth, lactation, reproduction, maintenance of pregnancy, egg laying, weaning, fattening etc

questions.question: Which of the following type of rations will supplies the animal with just the quantity of nutrients that are enough to enable the animal carry on with vital body activities without losing or gaining another substance
questions.correction: A maintenance ration is the amount of feed needed to prevent an increase or decrease in the weight of the animal. The ration will just be enough to maintain the supplies of energy and protein for all metabolic activities such as respiration, blood circulation, digestion, locomotion, maintenance of body temperature.

questions.question: The quantity of ration that can supply the requirement nutrients above the maintenance to enable the animal produce the form of animal product for which the livestock is kept is known as
questions.correction: The production ration can be for meat, growth, milk, wool and egg production. The food is supplied in excess of maintenance requirements.

questions.question: Which of the following classes of nutrient is used only for energy production in farm animals?
questions.correction: Carbohydrates are the main source of energy for the body. They are sugars, starches and dietary fibre.

questions.question: ________ is a disease condition which emanates from inadequate nutrition.
questions.correction: Nutritional deficiency is therefore defined as a disease condition which emanates from inadequate nutrition. It is indicated by specific symptoms when particular nutrients are absent or unavailable in the diet.

questions.question: Preservation of fish prevents the following except
questions.correction: Preservation prevents spoilage, injury or destruction and this keeps the fish in edible condition for a long time. Preservation does not prevent processing

questions.question: Which of the following is a powerful and expensive multipurpose motor vehicle used for lifting or pulling farm implements?
questions.correction:
-TRACTOR: It is a powerful and expensive multipurpose motor vehicle used for lifting or pulling farm implements
-BULLDOZERS: They are powerful tractors and expensive machines with a broad steel blade or sheet at the front.
-SHELLERS: These are machines operated electrically, mechanically or manually. Shellers are used to separate the seeds from the husk or cob.
-INCUBATORS: These are machines which are used for hatching fertilized eggs artificially.

questions.question: The following are types of planters except
questions.correction: RIDGER: It is a secondary tillage implement used for land preparation, it is used after harrow and before planter.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of harvester?
questions.correction: PLOUGH:This is a primary tillage implement which is attached to a tractor. It is the first implement required in land preparation. Others are types of harvester.

questions.question: The followings are functions of a sprayer except
questions.optiona: It can be used to control the growth of weeds
questions.optionb: It can be used to control the effects of pest.
questions.optionc: It can be used to plant seeds
questions.optiond: It can be used to spray disinfectant.
questions.correction: Sprayers are types of equipment designed to spray certain chemicals in various farm operations and not for planting seeds.

questions.question: Which of these is not an example of tractor coupled implement?
questions.correction:
Tractor coupled implements are implements which are coupled or attached to a tractor in order to enable if perform its work. They are also called intermediate farm machinery.
Incubators are machines which are used for hatching fertilized eggs artificially and they are not attached to a tractor.

questions.question: ___________ is the process which assist farmers through educational procedures in improving farming methods
questions.correction: Agricultural extension is the process, system or service which assists farmers or farm people through educational procedures in improving farming methods and techniques.

questions.question: One of the followings is not an objective of agricultural extension
questions.optionb: To help improve the standard of living of rural dwellers
questions.optionc: To abandon the development of rural area
questions.optiond: To help identify proper market channel
questions.correction: Agricultural extension help accelerate the development of rural area and not abandon them

questions.question: The principles of agricultural extension includes the following except
questions.optiond: Reduce the confidence of your audience
questions.correction: other options are principles of agricultural extension except to reduce the confidence of your audience

questions.question: __________is used to create awareness and interest in the new ideas and techniques among the majority of the people
questions.correction: mass media method enables many people to know about the new innovation. This method involves the use of publications,leaflets,posters,agricultural shows and exhibitions

questions.question: The following are examples of agricultural extension except
questions.correction: Examples of extension Programmes include: Agricultural Development Programme(ADP), Farm Settlement Scheme, Agro-Service Centres, Research Institutes,Green revolution programme, Operation feed the nation

questions.question: What is the primary characteristic of weeds in agriculture?
questions.optiona: They are beneficial for crop growth
questions.optionb: They compete with crops for resources
questions.optionc: They are cultivated intentionally by farmers
questions.optiond: They do not require any maintenance
questions.correction: The primary characteristic of weeds in agriculture is that they compete with crops for resources. Weeds are unwanted plants that grow in agricultural fields and compete with cultivated crops for sunlight, water, nutrients, and space. They can reduce crop yields by depriving crops of essential resources and sometimes release chemicals that inhibit crop growth.

questions.question: Which of the following is a potential disadvantage of agricultural extension?
questions.optiona: Lack of access to extension services in remote areas
questions.optiond: Enhanced adoption of improved farming practices
questions.correction: One of the potential disadvantages of agricultural extension is the lack of access to extension services in remote areas. Agricultural extension services aim to provide information, education, and support to farmers, enabling them to adopt improved farming practices and enhance their productivity. However, in remote or geographically isolated regions, the availability of extension services may be limited or non-existent.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of mixed cropping in agriculture?
questions.optiona: Maximizing the yield of a single crop
questions.optionc: Enhancing soil fertility through crop rotation
questions.optiond: Reducing the risk of crop failure
questions.correction: The primary purpose of mixed cropping in agriculture is to reduce the risk of crop failure. Mixed cropping involves growing two or more different crops together in the same field. This practice helps farmers mitigate the potential negative impacts of pests, diseases, adverse weather conditions, and market fluctuations that can affect a single crop.

questions.question: Which of the following is a form of land ownership in which an individual holds complete ownership and control over a piece of land?
questions.correction: Freehold is a form of land ownership in which an individual holds complete ownership and control over a piece of land. The individual has the right to use, sell, or transfer the land as they wish, subject to legal regulations. This form of ownership is often associated with privately owned properties, where the land is owned outright and not subject to any time-limited agreements.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a pasture in agriculture?
questions.correction: The primary purpose of a pasture in agriculture is to provide grazing animals with forage. A pasture is an area of land specifically designated for the purpose of growing and providing vegetation for livestock to graze on. It consists of various grasses, legumes, and other suitable plants that are palatable and nutritious for animals.

questions.question: How are farm animals classified based on their feeding habits?
questions.correction: Farm animals are commonly classified based on their feeding preferences. This classification categorizes animals into different groups based on their dietary habits and the type of feed they consume.

questions.question: Which of the following is a branch of agriculture that focuses on the cultivation of fruits, vegetables, and ornamental plants?
questions.correction: Horticulture is a branch of agriculture that focuses on the cultivation, management, and production of fruits, vegetables, and ornamental plants. It includes practices related to the growing, harvesting, processing, and marketing of horticultural crops. Horticulturists may specialize in areas such as fruit production, vegetable farming, floriculture (ornamental plants and flowers), or nursery operations.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of farm machinery used for planting seeds?
questions.correction: A seed drill is an example of farm machinery used for planting seeds. It is a device or implement designed to precisely sow seeds at a consistent depth and spacing.

questions.question: What does the scale of preference represent in agricultural decision-making?
questions.optiona: The ranking of available choices based on personal preference
questions.optionb: The availability of resources for agricultural production
questions.optionc: The total cost of implementing different agricultural practices
questions.optiond: The market demand for agricultural products
questions.correction: The scale of preference represents the ranking of available choices based on personal preference in agricultural decision-making. When making choices in agriculture, farmers and agricultural stakeholders evaluate different options and rank them according to their preferences and goals.

questions.question: Which of the following is a primary function of the digestive system?
questions.correction: The primary function of the digestive system is the absorption of nutrients. The digestive system breaks down food into smaller molecules through processes such as mechanical digestion (chewing) and chemical digestion (enzymes breaking down food).

questions.question: What is the primary goal of crop improvement in agriculture?
questions.correction: The primary goal of crop improvement in agriculture is to enhance crop yield and quality. Crop improvement involves various techniques, such as plant breeding, genetic engineering, and selection of superior traits, to develop new varieties or cultivars with improved characteristics. These characteristics may include higher yields, improved nutritional content, resistance to pests and diseases, tolerance to environmental stresses, and better adaptation to specific growing conditions.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common method of disseminating information to farmers?
questions.correction: Disseminating information to farmers involves utilizing various methods to reach them effectively. Social media campaigns, such as through platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and WhatsApp, have become increasingly popular for sharing agricultural knowledge, news, and updates. Radio broadcasts, especially in rural areas, serve as an important means of reaching farmers with relevant agricultural information.

questions.question: Which of the following periods marked the beginning of agricultural practices by early human societies?
questions.correction: The Paleolithic Age, also known as the Stone Age, marked the beginning of agricultural practices by early human societies. During this period, which began around 2.6 million years ago and lasted until around 10,000 BCE, humans transitioned from being solely hunter-gatherers to engaging in early forms of agriculture.

questions.question: What is the role of agricultural extension officers in the field of agriculture?
questions.optionc: Conducting research on new farming techniques
questions.optiond: Delivering agricultural education and training to farmers
questions.correction: The role of agricultural extension officers in the field of agriculture is primarily to deliver agricultural education and training to farmers. Agricultural extension officers work closely with farmers, providing them with information, knowledge, and technical expertise to improve their farming practices. They facilitate the transfer of scientific research and technology to farmers, helping them adopt modern and sustainable agricultural practices.

questions.question: What is the primary function of the reproductive system in farm animals?
questions.optionb: Reproduction and propagation of the species
questions.correction: The primary function of the reproductive system in farm animals is the reproduction and propagation of the species. The reproductive system in farm animals, including cows, sheep, pigs, and poultry, is responsible for the production of gametes (sperm and eggs) and facilitating the process of fertilization. It involves the functioning of reproductive organs, such as the ovaries, testes, uterus, and oviducts, as well as hormone regulation.

questions.question: What is the primary function of the reproductive system in farm animals?
questions.optionb: Reproduction and propagation of the species
questions.correction: The primary function of the reproductive system in farm animals is the reproduction and propagation of the species. The reproductive system in farm animals, including cows, sheep, pigs, and poultry, is responsible for the production of gametes (sperm and eggs) and facilitating the process of fertilization. It involves the functioning of reproductive organs, such as the ovaries, testes, uterus, and oviducts, as well as hormone regulation.

questions.question: What does the concept of demand and supply refer to in agriculture?
questions.optiona: The government's role in regulating agricultural prices
questions.optionb: The distribution of agricultural resources among different regions
questions.optionc: The quantity of agricultural products produced and consumed
questions.optiond: The interaction between buyers and sellers in agricultural markets
questions.correction: The concept of demand and supply in agriculture refers to the interaction between buyers and sellers in agricultural markets. It is based on the principle that the quantity of agricultural products demanded by consumers and the quantity supplied by producers determine the equilibrium price and quantity in the market.

questions.question: What is the primary goal of genetic engineering in agriculture?
questions.optiona: Creating genetically modified organisms (GMOs) with desirable traits
questions.optionb: Preserving traditional farming practices and crop varieties
questions.optionc: Eliminating the use of pesticides and fertilizers in farming
questions.optiond: Enhancing crop yields through traditional breeding methods
questions.correction: The primary goal of genetic engineering in agriculture is to create genetically modified organisms (GMOs) with desirable traits. Genetic engineering involves manipulating the genetic material of organisms, such as plants, to introduce specific genes from other organisms.

questions.question: Farm animals can be classified into three main categories based on their primary purpose. Which of the following is NOT one of those categories?
questions.correction: Farm animals can be classified into three main categories based on their primary purpose: livestock animals, poultry, and companion animals. Livestock animals include cattle, sheep, goats, pigs, and other large mammals primarily raised for meat, milk, or fiber production. Poultry refers to birds such as chickens, turkeys, ducks, and geese, which are raised for meat and egg production. Companion animals encompass animals such as horses, dogs, and cats that are primarily kept for companionship, recreation, or other non-agricultural purposes.

questions.question: What is the term used to describe the deliberate modification of an organism's genetic material using biotechnology techniques?
questions.correction: Genetic engineering is the term used to describe the deliberate modification of an organism's genetic material using biotechnology techniques. It involves the manipulation of an organism's DNA to introduce or alter specific traits. Genetic engineering techniques include gene insertion, deletion, or modification to achieve desired characteristics in plants, animals, or microorganisms.

questions.question: What is the primary focus of agronomy in agriculture?
questions.optionc: Study of climate and weather patterns
questions.optiond: Marketing and selling of agricultural products
questions.correction: The primary focus of agronomy in agriculture is the management of soil and crops. Agronomy is a branch of agricultural science that deals with the principles and practices of soil and crop management.

questions.question: What happens to the price of a agricultural product when demand exceeds supply?
questions.correction: In economics, when demand exceeds supply, it creates a shortage. The price of the product will increase until the quantity demanded is equal to the quantity supplied, a state known as equilibrium. This is because the high demand and low supply create a competitive market where buyers are willing to pay more to secure the product.

questions.question: What does the term "recombinant DNA" refer to in biotechnology?
questions.optionb: DNA replicated using polymerase chain reaction (PCR)
questions.optiond: DNA modified to contain genes from different organisms
questions.correction: The term "recombinant DNA" in biotechnology refers to DNA that has been modified or engineered to contain genes from different organisms. This process involves the insertion of specific genes or gene segments into the DNA of an organism, resulting in the creation of a new DNA sequence with combined genetic information.

questions.question: What is the process of introducing foreign genetic material into an organism called?

questions.question: What is the primary focus of animal husbandry in agriculture?

questions.question: What is the primary objective of agricultural research?

questions.question: What is the purpose of using a scale of preference in agricultural decision-making?

questions.question: Which part of a tractor is responsible for providing power to the attached implements or machinery?

questions.question: What is the relationship between demand and supply in agriculture?
